generif.text: The intracellular domain of cadherin-11 is not required for the induction of cell aggregation, adhesion or gap-junction formation

In PCNSL lactoferrin expression was upregulated (P < 0.0005).

we describe in detail the clinical phenotype of the original CDH11-related patient with Elsahy-Waters syndrome (EWS), as well as a previously unreported EWS-affected girl who was also found to have a novel homozygous truncating variant in CDH11, which confirms that EWS is caused by biallelic CDH11 loss of function mutations.

we revisited the question of the relationship between Cav1 and Stat3-ptyr705 in non-transformed mouse fibroblasts and in human lung carcinoma cells, by examining their effect at different cell densities.Our results demonstrate that Cav1 downregulates cadherin-11, by a mechanism which requires the Cav1 scaffolding domain. This cadherin-11 downregulation, leads to a reduction in cRac1 and Stat3 activity levels.
This study identifies a novel loss-of-function variant in CDH11 as a cause of BSGS and supports the role of cadherin-11 as a key player in axial and craniofacial malformations.

This study demonstrated that EPHB6-mutated cells acquire cell adhesion-mediated drug resistance (CAM-DR) in association with CDH11 expression and RhoA/focal adhesion kinase (FAK) activation. Targeted inhibition of EPHA2 or CDH11 reversed the acquired paclitaxel resistance, suggesting its potential clinical utility.

CDH11 is an inductor of metastatic signaling, and biomarker of poor prognosis in metastatic breast cells (MBCs). Exposure to anti-CDH11 antibody suppresses metastasis, reduces CDH11, fibronectin and beta-catenin expression, and abrogate the cancer stem cell-like traits of MBC cells. Ectopic expression of miR-335 suppresses CDH11, beta-catenin and vimentin expression, in concert with attenuated metastatic potentials.

summary: This gene encodes a type II classical cadherin from the cadherin superfamily, integral membrane proteins that mediate calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion. Mature cadherin proteins are composed of a large N-terminal extracellular domain, a single membrane-spanning domain, and a small, highly conserved C-terminal cytoplasmic domain. Type II (atypical) cadherins are defined based on their lack of a HAV cell adhesion recognition sequence specific to type I cadherins. Expression of this particular cadherin in osteoblastic cell lines, and its upregulation during differentiation, suggests a specific function in bone development and maintenance. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
